description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: Data should relate to all sites in the UK. This includes England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland.
We will treat your information securely and confidentially.

This survey is refreshed every two weeks. To avoid losing data and to help us provide real-time information please submit by the return by date, or at the latest before the next fortnightly survey goes live.
On average it takes 5 minutes to complete this survey once you have collected the information.
You can save a copy of your answers at the end of this questionnaire using the ’Download as PDF’ button.

contents.description: Please complete this survey even if you are a sole trader and it does not seem relevant to your business. All returns are important, as it allows decision-makers to understand how businesses of all sizes are performing in the current climate.
Thank you for participating in this important survey.
View the questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)
This survey has the following sections:
This section asks for the business’s trading status.
This section asks for information about your workforce such as:
This section asks for information about:

list: your business’s probation policy for new employees
types of contract used in your business
your business’s collective redundancy consultation process
Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) process
opt out of Working Time Regulation

contents.description: This section asks for information about the impact of US tariff changes on your business

The data from this survey is used widely to enable rapid response, and inform policy decisions about issues impacting UK businesses and the economy. This includes topics relating to business resilience, financial performance, trade and your workforce.
View the latest publication produced from this survey (this link opens in a new tab)

blocks.page_title: Trading status of your business section

contents.description: This section asks for the business’s trading status.

title.text: Which of the following statements best describes {ru_name}’s trading status?

description:
You can interpret ’trading’ as ’operating’.

Only select ’paused trading’ if all trading or operations have temporarily stopped.

options.label: Currently partially trading
options.description: For example, trading with reduced hours or staff numbers

options.label: Paused trading but intends to restart in the next two weeks
Paused trading and does not intend to restart in the next two weeks

contents.description: This section asks for information about your workforce such as:

title.text: Is {ru_name} using, or intending to use, increased homeworking as a permanent business model going forward?

description: If you are a sole trader and do not have a workforce, please base your answers on your own working arrangement.

question.title: Why is your business using, or intending to use, increased homeworking as a permanent business model going forward?

options.label: Ability to better match jobs to skills
Ability to recruit from a wider geographical pool in the UK
Ability to recruit from a wider geographical pool internationally
Reduced carbon emissions
options.description: For example, due to less travelling to and from the workplace

question.title: Why is your business not intending to use increased homeworking as a permanent business model going forward?

options.label: Concerns with integrating new starters into the workplace
Costs of employee equipment
options.description: For example, the technology and equipment required to enable homeworking such as laptops or desks

options.label: Reduced reliability and retention of staff

question.title: Which, if any, of the following skills has your business had a high demand for in the last 12 months?

options.label: Advanced digital skills
options.description: For example, animation, data science and programming skills

options.label: Basic digital skills
options.description: For example, emails, office based applications, using the internet and video conferencing

options.label: Customer service skills
options.description: For example, skills used in retail and hospitality

options.label: Management or leadership skills
options.description: For example, influencing others, managing staff and setting objectives

options.label: Manual skills
options.description: For example, skills used in construction and industrial trades

options.label: Transferable skills
options.description: For example, managing your own time, task prioritisation and teamwork

question.title: Which, if any, of the following skills does your workforce require extra support or training in?

options.label: Advanced digital skills
options.description: For example, animation, data science and programming skills

options.label: Basic digital skills
options.description: For example, emails, office based applications, using the internet and video conferencing

options.label: Customer service skills
options.description: For example, skills used in retail and hospitality

options.label: Management or leadership skills
options.description: For example, influencing others, managing staff and setting objectives

options.label: Manual skills
options.description: For example, skills used in construction and industrial trades

options.label: Transferable skills
options.description: For example, managing your own time, task prioritisation and teamwork

blocks.page_title: Extra support or training for the workforce

question.title: On average, how did employees’ hourly wages in July 2025 compare with employees’ hourly wages in the previous calendar month?
description: If you are a sole trader and do not have a workforce, please base your answers on your own working arrangement.

question.title: How have your business’s staffing costs changed over the last three months?

contents.description: Include:
Exclude:

question.title: How does your business expect staffing costs to change over the next three months?

contents.description: Include:
Exclude:

question.title: How does your business plan to adapt to any future increases in employment costs?

options.label: Reduce employee benefits
options.description: This refers to non-statutory perks or compensation that are provided to employees in addition to their base salaries and wages

options.label: Reduce wage increases for other employees

question.title: Which of the following challenges, if any, has your business experienced due to a shortage of workers?

options.label: Business had to pause trading entirely
Business had to recruit temporary workers
Had to pause trading of some of the business
Business has not experienced any challenges due to a shortage of workers

question.title: Which, if any, of the following employees has your business had difficulties recruiting in July 2025?

options.label: Clerical employees
options.description: For example, payroll clerks and secretaries

options.label: Professional or managerial employees
options.description: For example, accountants, lawyers and sales managers

options.label: Semi-skilled or unskilled employees
options.description: For example, bartenders, retail salespersons and security guards

options.label: Skilled, manual or technical employees
options.description: For example, carpenters, electricians and plumbers

options.label: Business did not experience any difficulties in recruiting employees

blocks.page_title: Type of employees business had difficulties in recruiting

question.title: Why did your business experience difficulties recruiting employees in July 2025?

options.label: Business cannot offer an attractive pay package to applicants
options.description: For example, additional benefits, competitive pay and flexible working hours

options.label: Increased number of vacancies
options.description: For example, business growth and diversification, or new work opportunities

options.label: Lack of qualified applicants for the roles on offer
options.description: For example, applicants lacking the experience, qualifications or skills required

options.label: Low number of applications for the roles on offer
Reduced number of applicants aged 16 to 24 years
Reduced number of applicants aged over 50 years

blocks.page_title: Reasons for difficulties faced in recruiting employees

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

list: your business’s probation policy for new employees
types of contract used in your business

title.text: Does {ru_name} have a probation policy in place for new employees?

question.title: How long is a typical probationary period for new employees at your business?
Does your business currently have any employees on any of the following contracts?

options.label: Agency contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker who has been supplied by a temporary work agency to work under the supervision and direction of a hirer.

options.label: Casual contract
options.description: This refers to an agreement with a worker without a formal contract of employment.

options.label: Fixed term contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker which is set out and agreed to last for up to 12 months.

options.label: Minimum hours contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker which guarantees them between 1 and 20 hours of work per week, but where they are regularly offered more hours, with the exact hours of work to be determined in accordance with business need.

options.label: Seasonal contract
options.description: This refers to a temporary contract of employment with a worker, which is used to cover temporary seasonal demand, such as for Christmas or summer.

options.label: Variable hours contract
options.description: This refers to an agreement with a fixed hourly rate of pay but without a guaranteed fixed number of hours per week. Alternatively, this also refers to an agreement with a fixed minimum number of hours per week but the worker is regularly offered hours of work beyond contractual obligations in accordance with business need.

options.label: Zero hours contract
options.description: This refers to a contract with a worker which clarifies that they may be asked to perform work, but there is no set minimum number of hours.

guidance.show_guidance: Why are we asking this question?
guidance.hide_guidance: Why are we asking this question?

contents.description: Your answer provides us with a better understanding of which types of contract are most used by different industries and how much they are relied on. Data from this question will be key in feeding into policy design.

question.title: Approximately, what percentage of your business’s workforce is employed under a variable hours contract?

guidance.show_guidance: Why are we asking this question?
guidance.hide_guidance: Why are we asking this question?

contents.description: Your answer provides us with a better understanding of which types of contract are most used by different industries and how much they are relied on. Data from this question will be key in feeding into policy design.

blocks.page_title: Percentage of workforce employed under variable hours contracts

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

list: change in volume of goods produced or services provided
effect of change on average cost per unit
your business’s geographical level of operation
locations your business currently operate from
price set for goods or services
new or significantly improved goods or services
new or significantly improved production technique

question.title: In the last 12 months, approximately what percentage of your business’s total annual expenses were fixed costs?

contents.description: This refers to expenses that stay the same no matter how much a business produces or sells, for example overhead costs such as rent, insurance, salary for permanent staff and property tax.

question.title: In the last 12 months, has your business experienced any change in the volume of goods produced, or services provided?

contents.description: Exclude any new goods or services introduced during this period

blocks.page_title: Change in volume of goods or services

question.title: What effect, if any, has this change had on your business’s average cost per unit?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’cost per unit’

contents.description: This refers to the expenditure associated with a specific quantity of good produced or service provided, such as cost per kg produced, cost per unit service provided or per hour of service provided.

options.label: A decrease in cost per unit
An increase in cost per unit
No effect on cost per unit

blocks.page_title: Effect of change on average cost per unit

title.text: At what geographical level does {ru_name} primarily operate?

contents.description: This refers to where your business mainly conduct its activities, not its registered location.

options.label: Local
options.description: This refers to a specific area such as town, city or local authority area.

options.label: Regional
options.description: This refers to a broader area that encompasses multiple towns, cities or local areas within a specific region

options.label: National
options.description: This refers to whole of UK, encompassing all regions

options.label: International
options.description: This refers to any country outside the UK

question.title: How many locations does your business currently operate from?
In the last 12 months, how were prices for your business’s goods or services set?

options.label: Both at individual location and at headquarters

blocks.page_title: Price set for goods or services

question.title: How do your business’s prices vary across different locations?

options.label: Prices differ in each business location
Prices are mostly the same in the UK, but different abroad
Prices are mostly the same irrespective of the business locations

question.title: Does your business conduct any online sales?

contents.description: Include sales from orders received over the internet regardless of how they are paid for or delivered

question.title: Has your business developed any new or significantly improved goods or services in the last 12 months?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’new or significantly improved’

contents.description: This refers to goods or services that the customer receives, which offer a significant improvement in function or performance.

blocks.page_title: New or significantly improved goods or services

question.title: Has your business implemented any new or significantly improved production techniques in the last 12 months?

definitions.title: What we mean by ’new or significantly improved production technique’

contents.description: This refers to new or improved methods, processes or technologies used internally to produce goods or deliver services

blocks.page_title: New or significantly improved production technique

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

list: other businesses currently offering similar goods or services
potential suppliers providing the key input

question.title: In the last 12 months, how intense has competition been in your business’s market?

contents.description: This refers to a high level of competition from businesses offering similar goods or services, often involving a large number of direct competitors and aggressive market strategies.

title.text: Approximately, how many other businesses currently offer similar goods or services to {ru_name}?

description: Consider both businesses operating in your reference market, as well as online businesses that offer similar goods or services to your main business activity.

question.title: For your business’s main good or service, how many suppliers could provide the key input?

contents.description: Include:

list: materials, energy, or services used in production

contents.description: Exclude:
This refers to the most essential material, resource, or component required to produce good or service.

guidance.show_guidance: What we mean by ’main good or service’
guidance.hide_guidance: What we mean by ’main good or service’

contents.description: This refers to either the one that brings the most profit or the one most frequently provided.

question.title: In the last 12 months, how important has maintaining low prices been to your business’s ability to remain competitive?
Which of the following factors, if any, would make it difficult for startups to succeed in your industry?

options.label: Challenging competitive environment
options.description: For example, difficulties in building brand recognition, saturated markets, loyalty to existing brands or consumer switching costs.

options.label: High upfront financial investments
options.description: For example, capital needed for equipment, premises, or staffing before operations can begin.

options.label: Lack of access to technology or expertise
options.description: For example, difficulties in obtaining the know-how, or tools intellectual property needed to operate effectively.

options.label: Limited access to materials or distribution channels
options.description: For example, existing business having exclusive contracts with suppliers or distributors.

options.label: Regulatory requirements
options.description: For example, administrative procedures or licensing requirements.

question.title: To what extent can your business’s goods or services be customised to meet individual needs?

contents.description: This refers to goods or services that has been tailored, modified, or personalised to meet specific needs or preferences

options.label: No customisation at all
options.description: This refers to modification possible to the goods or services provided.

options.label: Small customisation
options.description: This refers to goods or services that are standardised but can be modified to some extent.

options.label: Strong customisation
options.description: This refers to goods or services that are mainly or completely tailor made.

question.title: Which of the following best describes the overall market positioning of your business’s goods or services?

contents.description: This refers to how a business presents its goods or services in terms of quality and price to attract a specific customer segment. This approach reflects the business’s strategic focus, whether the aim is to compete based on price, value, or exclusivity.
This section asks for information regarding the types of data analysis used to support your business operations.

title.text: Which of the following types of data analysis, if any, does {ru_name} use to support its operations?

options.label: Descriptive qualitative data analysis
options.description: This refers to analysing qualitative data such as customer feedback, or effectiveness of social media presence.

options.label: Descriptive quantitative data analysis
options.description: For example measuring simple trends or comparisons across time periods.

options.label: Diagnostic data analysis
options.description: This refers to understanding why something has happened, for example through correlations, or causal identification.

options.label: Traditional predictive data analysis
options.description: This refers to understanding what will likely happen, for example through forecasting, or statistical models.

options.label: AI predictive data analysis
options.description: This refers to understanding what will likely happen, for example through machine learning and other AI-assisted techniques.

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

title.text: Has {ru_name} exported goods or services in the last 12 months?

contents.description: Include exporting services from your businesses in the UK to an individual or business located outside of the UK
This refers to skills and services that are provided by people and are ’intangible’.
For example, your business may provide a service, such as legal or financial services, to a non-UK business.

options.label: Business has not exported goods or services in the last 12 months

title.text: Has {ru_name} imported goods or services in the last 12 months?

contents.description: Include importing services from an individual or business located outside of the UK to your businesses in the UK
This refers to skills and services that are provided by people and are ’intangible’.
For example, your business may receive a service, such as research or construction, from a non-UK business.

options.label: Business has not imported goods or services in the last 12 months

contents.description: This section asks for information about:

list: the availability of materials, goods and services within the US
intentions to open any new branches or subsidiaries in the US
the impact of US tariff changes on your business

title.text: Was {ru_name} able to get the materials, goods or services it needed from the US in July 2025?

options.label: Yes, the business was able to get the materials, goods or services it needed
Yes, but the business had to change suppliers or find alternative solutions
No, the business was not able to get the materials, goods or services needed

blocks.page_title: Materials, goods or services from the US

question.title: Does your business intend to open any new branches or subsidiaries in the US in the next 12 months?

title.text: What impact, if any, did the United States tariffs have on {ru_name} in the last month?

contents.description: Include impacts from other countries in your supply chain that are being affected by the United States tariffs

options.label: Business passed additional costs to customers
Business stopped or paused exports to the United States

blocks.page_title: Impact of US tariffs in the last month

question.title: What impact, if any, do you expect the United States tariffs to have on your business in the next month?

contents.description: Include impacts from other countries in your supply chain that are being affected by the United States tariffs

options.label: Business will explore new export markets
Business will pass additional costs to customers
Business will stop or pause exports to the United States
No impact expected for the business

blocks.page_title: Impact of US tariffs in the next month

question.title: Please tell us anything else about your business’s current situation relating to topics covered in this survey
